briefOverview: The Lord directs the elders to assemble, promising an outpouring of the Spirit as they prepare to preach repentance and legally organize for protection. He also commands active care for the poor and needy.
summary: The Lord commands the elders to gather from all directions by letter or other means, promising His Spirit when they assemble in faith. After gathering, they are to go out to nearby regions and preach repentance, leading to many conversions. As conversions grow, they will gain power to organize themselves according to civil laws, so enemies will not overpower them and they can keep God’s laws. This organization is meant to preserve the community and break every bond imposed by adversaries. Finally, the Lord commands them to visit and relieve the poor and needy, sustaining them until all can be done according to the divine law they have already received.
externalContext: This revelation is historically situated in early 1831, soon after many converts of the Church of Christ (later The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints) had gathered to the Kirtland, Ohio, area. Rapid growth created both logistical and legal pressures, including questions about property, assembly, and communal support for impoverished members arriving from other regions. Early American religious movements often sought legal structures to protect assemblies and property. The call to gather elders for a conference aligns with early organizational meetings where leadership instructions and church order were clarified.
externalReferences: The phrase “my law which ye have received” likely points to the recently given “law” in Doctrine and Covenants 42, especially its directives to care for the poor (D&C 42:30–31). The mandate to organize “according to the laws of man” resonates with later instruction to obey civil authority (D&C 58:21). The call for preaching repentance echoes Jesus’s commission to preach repentance to all nations (Luke 24:47; see also Mark 6:12). The charge to visit and relieve the poor aligns with New Testament patterns of communal care (Acts 4:32–35) and the ethic of pure religion (James 1:27).

sectionTitles.title: Relief for the poor and needy

practicalQuestions: How can faith-filled gatherings prepare us to receive the Spirit more fully?
In what nearby “regions” of my life and community should I actively preach repentance and hope?
What steps can our congregation take to be legally and administratively organized for wise stewardship and protection?
How am I personally visiting and relieving the poor and needy in sustainable, respectful ways?
Where might fear of opposition be keeping me from organizing and acting to keep God’s laws?
uncertainAreas: “Organize yourselves according to the laws of man” could refer to various legal steps (incorporation, property management, or meeting regulations), and the text does not specify which. “Every bond may be broken” could be metaphorical (spiritual or social constraints) or literal (legal or economic bondage). The exact identity of the “enemies” and the details of “my law which ye have received” are not fully spelled out here, though D&C 42 is a strong candidate.
